occurrences.line_text: From the departing land it launched light,
But that sweet bird departing, flew forth right
Of his departure thence; for of her ioy
But when of his departure she despayrd,
That his departure thence should be so short,
For his departure, her new cause of griefe;
Or greedily depasturing delight:
Depeincted was, full easie to be knowne,
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
For more on him doth then him selfe depend;
They all are Graces, which on her depend,
And sleeues dependant Albanese-wyse:
Whose dangerous successe depended yet in dout.
Depending from on high, dreadfull to sight,
The cause of both, of both their minds depends;
Seemed some great misfortune to deplore,
Other then my hard fortune to deplore,
His hard mishap in dolor to deplore,
Vnto the wyld wood ranne, her dolours to deplore.
As if she did some great calamitie deplore.
Downe to the house of dole, his daies there to deplore.
Let them that list, their lucklesse lot deplore;
That nought him grieu'd to bene from rule deposed downe.
Deposed was from Princedome soueraine,
How to depraue, or slaunderously vpbrayd,
Thus answer'd; Lewdly thou my loue deprauest,
Did fall to ground, depriu'd of natiue might;
Whom that mad man of life nigh late depriu'd,
Ne wonder then, if that he were depriu'd
And them of their vniust possession depriu'd.
Of whom they ouer-comen, were depriu'd
And thereby deemd the beast had bene depriu'd
Depriu'd of kindly ioy and naturall delight.
It had depriu'd her mother of a daughter.
In bloudie field: therefore of life him not depriue.
Of endlesse life he might him not depriue,
Desired rest, and men of happinesse depriue.
But both of comfort him thou shalt depriue,
By treacherous deceipt did me depriue;
That each of life sought others to depriue,
But she with blame would blot, & of due praise depriue.
Out of their wretched corses, and their liues depriue.
But all in his reuenge of spirite would depriue.
When her that Tyrant did of Crowne depriue;
His worke, for which he was by Ioue depriued
But she, as one nigh of her wits depriued,
Wherewith she many had of life depriued,
He surely dempt, himselfe he thought depriued
In whom he liu'd a new, of former life depriued.
Whereof that Tyrant had her now depriued,
And with them practiz'd, how for to depryue
Whose depth exceeded not three cubits hight,
Was drowned in the depth of deadly sleepe,
Thinking to hide the depth by troubling of the flood.
The waters depth, and doth their bottome tread;
And all the depth of rightfull doome was taught
And durst the depth of any water sownd.
Whose counsels depth thou canst not vnderstand,
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
Now drowned in the depth of sleepe all fearelesse lay.
Me ill besits, that in der-doing armes,
Was lincked, and by him had many pledges dere.
But that same Squire, to whom she was more dere,
That is berobbed of her youngling dere,
And eke that Idoll deem'd so costly dere;
Vnworthy she to be belou'd so dere,
That she did loue a stranger swayne then him more dere.
Like as a Lion mongst an heard of dere,
And makes wrong doers iustice to deride,
Thy courteous lore, that doest my loue deride,
Did laugh at her, that many did deride,
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
And old records from auncient times deriu'd,
Vntill that Brutus anciently deriu'd
That from one roote deriu'd their vitall sap:
Return'd to heauen, whence she deriu'd her race;
Vp to the skies, whence first deriu'd it was,
Planted in earth, being deriu'd at furst
Whose lignage from this Lady I deriue along.
From him my linage I deriue aright,
Which from great Neptune do deriue their parentage.
Deriued are, and all this worldes blis
Which though from earth it be deriued right,
From this renowmed Prince deriued arre,
A man, of many partes from beasts deriued,
What mister wight that was, and whence deriued,
But through traduction was eftsoones deriued,
Of noble minds deriued from aboue,
Whence all the world deriues the glorious
Their puissance, whylome full dernely tryde:
Dernely vnto her called to abstaine,
Drad for his derring do, and bloudy deed;
All mightie men and dreadfull derring dooers,
Renowmed much in armes and derring doe:
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
To bring forth fruit, and make eternall derth,
That she might it vnto her selfe deryue,
T'adorne thy forme according thy desart,
Lesse she thee lou'd, then was thy iust desart,
Lo there Sir Paridel, for your desart,
What vengeance due can equall thy desart,
Deliuer from the doome of my desart,
Three hundred pledges for my good desartes,
And not regard dew right and iust desarts?
Yet he of malice, without her desarts,
The blessed Angels to and fro descend
Thy fruitfull Ofspring, shall from thee descend;
From whence descend all hopelesse remedies:
From whom I Paridell by kin descend;
The hight, and downe descend vnto the base.
Did forth descend, there being none them neare,
That deepe descended through the hollow ground,
Which now thou bear'st, to thee descended farre
In hast she from her lofty chaire descended,
Into the Martian field adowne descended,
His soule descended downe into the Stygian reame.
And with such monstrous poise adowne descended,
For sooth he was descended of the hous
The which descended with such dreadfull sway,
Were downe to them descended in that earthly vew.
Thence forth descending to that perlous Porch,
Therefore descending backe in haste, he sought
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
And euen as his right hand adowne descends,
And by descent from Royall lynage came
Of th'high descent, whereof he was yborne,
But all a deepe descent, as darke as hell,
Ne that approcheth nigh the wide descent,
What boots it boast thy glorious descent,
Which of them sprung by lineall descent:
Euen thrise eleuen descents the crowne retaynd,
And all their Ofspring, in their dew descents,
Thou doest effect in destined descents,
I not descerned in that darkesome shade,
Great Venus Temple is describ'd,
Him thus describ'd, to be of stature large,
Cannot describe, nor wit of man can tell;
Long were it to describe the goodly frame,
Described by that famous Tuscane penne:
By many signes, which she described had,
describeth Artegall:
Whose sober lookes her wisedome well descride:
But all so soone, as he from far descride
That he descride, and shonned still his slight:
Whilst reason blent through passion, nought descride,
Worse is the daunger hidden, then descride.
For th'one of them he perfectly descride,
Sent forth their Squire to haue them both descride,
In quyent disguise, full hard to be descride.
Who soone as them approaching he descride,
And drawing nigh, when as he plaine descride
Him seeking euermore, yet no where him descride.
Ne euer from the day the night descride,
(An vncouth sight) he plainely then descride
Well weend she then, ere him she plaine descride,
His name was Blandamour, that did descrie
She through his late disguizeme[n]t could him not descrie.
Yet further right by tokens to descrie,
In lieu whereof he would to him descrie,
Descried streight; who all the citty warned,
How shall fraile pen descriue her heauenly face,
In her owne breast, this mothers ioy descriue:
As to descry the crafty cunning traine,
And all so soyld, that none could him descry;
A darkesome way, which no man could descry,
Then said the knight, Loe I the land descry,
But by the checked waue they did descry
That they it past, and shortly gan descry
Tho when her wayes he could no more descry,
Through the tops of the high trees she did descry
Expecting euer, when some foe she might descry.
So blind is lust, false colours to descry.
But well I wote, that these which I descry,
That who he was, vneath was to descry;
To weete if shipping readie he mote there descry.
That round about her iawes one might descry
He could no path nor tract of foot descry,
O What an easie thing is to descry
Mote them descry, nor reskue from their pray,
For doubtlesse death ensewd, if any him descryde.
And eke be safe from daunger far descryde:
The doubtfull Mayd, seeing her selfe descryde,
And at her ran: she hauing him descryde,
To saue his life, ne let him be descryde,
Who[m] when they nigh approcht, they plaine descryde
Fighting on foot, as well he him descryde,
As well may be in Calidore descryde,
By certaine signes he plainely him descryde,
But kept aloofe for dread to be descryde,
For dread of them vnwares to be descryde,
To their deseigne to make the easier way,
Ay wont in desert darknesse to remaine,
Then brought she me into this desert waste,
By dew desert of noble cheualree,
To thinke without desert of gentle deed,
That nought but desert wildernesse shew'd all around.
That here in desert hast thine habitaunce,
Or dye with honour and desert of fame;
With his dull vapour all that desert has,
That to all high desert and honour doth aspire.
Deeme of her high desert, or seeme so light:
She grew familiare in that desert place.
To leaue that desert mansion, she cast
That seemed some blacksmith dwelt in that desert grou[n]d.
Till on a day as through a desert wyld
Backe to that desert forrest they retyred,
The Gate of good desert, whose goodly pride
The meede of his desert for that despight,
Who though he were still in this desert wood,
Amongst wilde beastes in desert forrests bred,
In wildernesse and wastfull deserts strayd,
Long she thus traueiled through deserts wyde,
In saluage forrests, and in deserts wide,
For oft their lewdnes blotteth good deserts with blame.
In these wylde deserts, where she now abode,
Not with so good successe, as she deseru'd;
The dreadfull Fish, that hath deseru'd the name
For his deare sake, that ill deseru'd that plight:
Ne did it then deserue a name to haue,
Thy life she gaue, thy life she doth deserue:
Did aske me, how I could her loue deserue,
Marching in louely wise, that could deserue
And she most fit his seruice doth deserue,
And readie to deserue, what grace I found.
He wold by all good means he might, deserue such grace.
To punish those, that doe deserue the same;
Yet praise likewise deserue good thewes, enforst with paine.
From whence he tooke his well deserued name:
So brought vnto his Lord, as his deserued pray.
Right well deserued as his duefull meed,
Deserued for their perils recompense.
And place deserued with the Gods on hy.
That Marinell that day deserued best.
That neuer did her ill, ne once deserued blame.
And speake so ill of him, that well deserued,
That neuer so deserued to endite.
Or euer do, that mote deseruen blame:
Deserues to tast his follies fruit, repented payne.
Another Grace she well deserues to be,
But his owne guiltie mind deseruing death.
That seemd some perilous tumult to desine,
Desird of forreine foemen to be knowne,
That his disciples both desir'd to bee;
And to possesse the purpose they desird:
But seeing still the more desir'd to see,
First he desir'd their cause of strife to see:
The wretched mayd that earst desir'd to die,
Talus desir'd, that he might haue prepared
And greatly it desir'd of her to learne,
Nigh to the place, which ye desir'd to see:
That he desirde to end his wretched dayes:
And homebred euill ye desire to heare,
Her captiue to his sensuall desire,
That rather death desire, then such despight.
Whiles he himselfe with greedie great desire
Iwill reuele, what ye so much desire:
With fresh desire his voyage to pursew:
O neuer Sir desire to try his guilefull traine.
Why then doest thou, O man of sin, desire
And bad him choose, what death he would desire:
To shew it to this knight, according his desire.
And after litle rest, gan him desire,
Death better were, death did he oft desire,
Or why should euer I henceforth desire,
Neither to melt in pleasures whot desire,
She broke his wanton darts, and quenched base desire.
His wandring thought in deepe desire does steepe,
led into loose desire,
Forth launched quickly, as she did desire,
Might not reuiue desire of knightly exercize.
But fairely tempring fond desire subdewd,
A couetous desire with his huge threasury.
Of which the matter of his huge desire
That was Ambition, rash desire to sty,
Sith wrathfull hand wrought not her owne desire?
And infinite desire into your spirite poure!
For losse of thousand liues, to dye at her desire.
My whole desire hath beene, and yet is now,
Who gently answered, They entrance did desire.
Through great desire of glory and of fame:
To read those bookes; who gladly graunted their desire.
Their minds to praise, and cheualrous desire:
And naturall desire of countreys state,
That shortly brent into extreme desire,
And in each gentle hart desire of honour breeds.
Such loue is hate, and such desire is shame.
And all attonce discouered her desire
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
Can haue no end, nor hope of my desire,
To compasse thy desire, and find that loued knight.
Of the young Damzell sunke, that great desire
It stirreth vp to sensuall desire,
And daughter of a woody Nymphe, desire
And beareth fruit of honour and all chast desire.
All that to come into the world desire;
But well I weene, ye first desire to learne,
As vnto her to vtter his desire;
Whom she did meane to make the thrall of her desire.
Was shut to all, which lodging did desire:
Shewing desire her inward flame to slake:
The God of his desire, the ioy of misers blind.
With greedy will, and enuious desire,
Whence dearely she with death bought her desire.
Whose chiefe desire is loue and friendly aid
But Ate soone discouering his desire,
O   Why doe wretched men so much desire,
Therewith to bind lasciuious desire,
That needed much her weake age to desire,
Returning, disappointed his desire,
No longer space thereto he did desire,
She in my stead supplide his bestiall desire.
And euermore he greatly did desire
For most of strength and beautie his desire
For losse of her new loue, the hope of her desire.
Eftsoones all burning with a fresh desire,
To take on him that paine: whose great desire
But since ye so desire, your will be donne.
But on chast vertue grounded their desire,
Might frankely there their loues desire possesse;
To bath in ioy and amorous desire,
To come where thou doest draw them with desire:
What thing so many nations met, did there desire.
The cause of their array, and truce for to desire.
For great desire, that Monster to assay,
And impotent desire of men to raine,
To Crudor, and desire him that he would
And thus replide; Faire chyld, the high desire
Him thus bespake; My liefe, my lifes desire,
Subdue desire, and bridle loose delight,
The noble childe preuenting his desire,
He staide his hand according her desire,
Ne could with seeing satisfie his great desire.
When pride of youth forth pricked my desire,
And to insinuate his harts desire,
Whom catching greedily for great desire,
To hinder soule from her desired rest,
And euer her desired to depart.
And reft from men the worlds desired vew,
Desired rest, and men of happinesse depriue.
With sober words, that sufferance desired,
Had not those two him instantly desired
That many Lords haue her to wife desired:
Him oft desired home with her to wend,
Desired be, or thence to banish bale:
That her alone he for his part desired
Inueigled him to follow her desires vnmeete.
In chaines of lust and lewd desires ybound,
And swimming deepe in sensuall desires,
So th'other did mens rash desires apall,
And chaste desires do nourish in your mind,
The same behold, therewith their keene desires were whet.
But stirred vp with different desires,
And let, what euer he desires, be him denide.
Disdeining life, desiring leaue to die,
And with reuenge desiring soone to dye,
Desiring of his Amoret to heare
She no lesse glad, then he desirous was
The rest hid vnderneath, him more desirous made.
Therefore desirous th'end of all their dayes
Desirous both to haue the battell donne;
In presence came, desirous t'vnderstand
Being desirous (as all Knights are woont)
Who though desirous rather to rest mute,
And eke desirous of the offred meed,
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
The Lyon would not leaue her desolate,
There find the virgin dolefull desolate,
Thenceforth me desolate he quite forsooke,
To aide a virgin desolate foredonne.
But was all desolate, and of some thought
But since this Ladie is all desolate,
Whom she beholding, now all desolate
Then here to see all desolate and wast,
Long wayted, saw his sudden desolation,
Is from her knight diuorced in despaire
If then it find not helpe, and breedes despaire.
Despaire breedes not (quoth he) where faith is staid.
A man of hell, that cals himselfe Despaire:
To driue him to despaire, and quite to quaile,
Vile Caytiue, vassall of dread and despaire,
O daughter deare (said she) despaire no whit;
Of sorrow and despaire without aleggeaunce?
That deedes of armes had euer in despaire,
His expectation to despaire did turne,
Spending his daies in dolour and despaire,
And all dismayd through mercilesse despaire,
Through dolorous despaire, which she conceyued,
In sad despaire, and all thy senses swowned
Adicia to despaire.
In sauing him from daungerous despaire
High God, whose goodnesse he despaired quight,
At last them driuen hath to this despairefull drift.
But when of his departure she despayrd,
Sir Treuisan flies from Despayre,
None else to death this man despayring driue,
Why shouldst thou then despeire, that chosen art?
Which to his mother told, despeire she from her flong.
Else should afflicted wights oftimes despeire.
In Cornewale, till that he through liues despeire
Dismaied with so desperate deadly wound,
With that all desperate as loathing light,
His sinfull soule with desperate disdaine,
He knockt his brest with desperate intent,
From her dull horse, in desperate distresse,
My Ladies loue, in such a desperate case,
All desperate of his fore-damned spright,
Twixt dolour and despight halfe desperate,
Ne desperate of glorious victorie,
Then death it selfe more dread and desperate.
The other almost dead and desperate
Desperate daunger, if he them assay,
The first of them by name was cald Despetto,
But stout Despetto in his greater pryde,
Death and despeyre did many thereof sup,
Yet doe I not of better times despeyre;
So daunted was in his despeyring mood,
He thought haue slaine her in his fierce despight:
And wast his inward gall with deepe despight,
Bitter despight, with rancours rusty knife,
No knight, but treachour full of false despight
And quench the flame of furious despight,
That rather death desire, then such despight.
To do her dye (quoth Vna) were despight,
And yeeldes his caytiue neck to victours most despight.
To be auenged of so great despight;
And of so fierce and forcible despight,
For griefe thereof, and diuelish despight,
For if he liue, that hath you doen despight,
Death were too little paine for such a foule despight.
As bound by them to liue in liues despight,
Streight downe againe her selfe in great despight
Her hellish brond hath kindled with despight,
Of that despight, neuer to wearen none;
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
In foule reproch, and termes of vile despight,
Occasion, the root of all wrath and despight.
And more for ranck despight, then for great paine,
What great despight doth fortune to thee beare,
I home returning, fraught with fowle despight,
Vpon my selfe that vengeable despight
In poyson and in bloud, of malice and despight.
The sonnes of old Acrates and Despight,
Headed with ire and vengeable despight;
And weetlesse eke of lately wrought despight,
He then vprose, inflam'd with fell despight,
So puissant foe, with enuious despight
Readie to drowne himselfe for fell despight.
Cruell Reuenge, and rancorous Despight,
Mote ought allay the storme of your despight,
His honour staines with rancour and despight,
But in despight of life, for death do call.
And euery loup fast lockt, as fearing foes despight.
She triumphed on death, in enemies despight.
And yet the vanquished had no despight:
That death me liefer were, then such despight,
Which forth he sent with felonous despight,
Loue and despight attonce her courage kindled hath.
By this forbidden way in my despight,
She, she it is, that hath me done despight:
And cast t'auenge him of that fowle despight,
Vile rancour their rude harts had fild with such despight.
But thou doest weene with villeinous despight,
Yet no'te she find redresse for such despight.
Yet to auenge his deuilish despight,
For great despight of that vnwonted band,
The quarrey throwes to ground with fell despight,
The rest she fyr'd for sport, or for despight;
Twixt inward doole and felonous despight;
Griefe, and despight, and gealosie, and scorne
This is (quoth he) the dolorous despight,
In which that boy thee plonged, for despight,
Led of two grysie villeins, th'one Despight,
The which he thought, for villeinous despight,
Twixt dolour and despight halfe desperate,
He now vnable was to wreake his old despight.
But Scudamour for passing great despight
Whose Lord hath done my loue this foule despight?
Yet Blandamour with termes of foule despight,
They stemme ech other with so fell despight,
And left the head behind: with which despight
But rather stird to vengeance and despight,
And in reuengement of his owne despight,
And woxe nigh mad for very harts despight,
On whom I waite to wreake that foule despight,
For fell despight, and gnaw his gealous hart,
With fell despight her cruell arrowes tynde
So on him selfe to wreake his follies owne despight.
For she was stuft with rancour and despight
Sixe they were all, all full of fell despight,
For old despight, which now forth newly brake
For hatred, murther, treason, and despight,
But bit his lip for felonous despight,
Most voide of guile, most free from fowle despight,
He for a twelue moneths day shall in despight
It bit the earth for very fell despight,
For as the death he hated such despight,
I rather chose to die in liues despight,
For neuer had she suffred such despight.
Nought could he do, but shun the dred despight
Yet he it tooke in his owne selfes despight,
